column4: I've broken my ntfs partition, but I know what's wrong. In the partitiontable it says the partition starts at 63 but it actually starts at 64. How do I fix this?
I'm not sure if there's an easy way to fix that
Then what's the hard way? :P
my advice would be to back up the partition table and take a hex editor to it
you might also be able to do it with fdisk or gparted, but I'm not so sure about that
as long as you keep all of the relevant info handy, you could redo the partition table and it won't format anything
What if I request to move the partition but stop the operation as soon as it corrected the table?
I think fdisk is transaction-based, it might rollback
don't quote me on that though
I would advise that you backup the partition, just in case
I've shot myself in the foot quite a few times by assuming there was nothing important on a partition
How? It's no longer readable
you could do dd if=/dev/(partition) of=backup
that will do a raw dump of the data on the partition
Well there is only one file I could possibly want to keep, which is mpdata containing my CoD4 rank
Other than that I try not to have important files on system disks
I store those on my 1TB data drive :D
And that rank is not worth the trouble
So I'm just going to throw it away, thanks anyway
alright, just keeping an eye out, because I've lost important data like that before
Me too, that's why I bought that 1TB drive ;)
I've been in a situation where I've had to manually fetch the data that was accidentally deleted from a coworker's ext3 partition; it's not pretty.
